column4: Mexico's Televisa considers legal steps in breakdown of deal with Live Nation
column5: MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Grupo Televisa on Tuesday said it would consider its legal options after talks with U.S. firm Live Nation Entertainment failed to reach an accord over the latter’s decision to pull out of a deal with the Mexican broadcaster.
column6: After Televisa’s announcement, its shares plummeted more than 6.7%.
column7: Last July, Televisa TLEVISACPO.MX said it had agreed to sell its stake in Mexican entertainment firm Ocesa to Live Nation LYV.N for around $290 million as part of the U.S. company's acquisition of 51% of Ocesa.
column8: Televisa held 40% of Ocesa and Mexican entertainment firm Corporacion Interamericana de Entretenimiento (CIE) around 11%.
column9: However, early this month Live Nation announced it was not going ahead with the deal.
column10: In a statement to the U.S. stock exchange, Live Nation said it was terminating the purchase agreement due to CIE’s failure to comply with certain contractual obligations.
column11: Televisa opposed the decision and so the parties began talks under a so-called suspension agreement, which has expired with no resolution, the Mexican firm said in a statement.
column12: “Televisa disagrees with the letter of termination and reserves its rights over the arguments previously made by Live Nation ... and will evaluate all recourses and actions available to it under existing agreements and laws,” it said.
column13: CIE said in a statement it would also analyze its legal options.

column4: Mexico's Televisa considers legal steps in breakdown of deal with Live Nation
column5: MEXICO CITY, May 26 (Reuters) - Grupo Televisa said on Tuesday it would consider its legal options after talks with U.S. firm Live Nation Entertainment failed to reach an accord over the latter’s decision to pull out of a deal with the Mexican broadcaster.
column6: Last July, Televisa said it had agreed to sell its stake in Mexican entertainment firm Ocesa to Live Nation for around $290 million as part of the U.S. company’s acquisition of 51% of Ocesa.
column7: Televisa held 40% of Ocesa and Mexican entertainment firm Corporacion Interamericana de Entretenimiento (CIE) around 11%.
column8: However, early this month Live Nation announced it was not going ahead with the deal.
column9: In a statement to the U.S. stock exchange, Live Nation said it was terminating the purchase agreement due to CIE’s failure to comply with certain contractual obligations.
column10: Televisa opposed the decision and so the parties began talks under a so-called suspension agreement, which has expired with no resolution, the Mexican firm said in a statement.
column11: “Televisa disagrees with the letter of termination and reserves its rights over the arguments previously made by Live Nation ... and will evaluate all recourses and actions available to it under existing agreements and laws,” it said.
column12: CIE said in a statement it would also analyze its legal options. (Reporting by Noe Torres and Abraham Gonzalez; Editing by Lisa Shumaker)

column4: Saudi Arabia's PIF discloses 5.7% stake in Live Nation
column5: (Reuters) - Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, the Public Investment Fund (PIF), disclosed a 5.7% passive stake in Live Nation Entertainment Inc LYV.N on Monday, sending the concert promoter's shares up 2% in early trading.
column6: The ownership of 12.34 million shares makes the investment fund the third-largest stakeholder in the company, according to Refinitiv data.
column7: PIF, which manages over $300 billion in assets, disclosed an 8.2% stake in coronavirus-hit Carnival Corp CCL.N earlier in April.
column8: Live Nation is an entertainment company that promotes events including ticketing, sponsorship and advertising services.
column9: The company, whose shares are down 44% so far this year, warned of a hit to its business earlier in April as a result of postponement or cancellation of shows due to the coronavirus pandemic.
column10: Liberty Media Corp FWONA.O is the largest shareholder in Live Nation, with a 25.05% stake, followed by Vanguard, which has a 7.09% stake according to Refinitiv data.

column4: Live Nation agrees to scrap retaliatory practices under Justice Dept pressure
column5: (Reuters) - Concert promoter Live Nation Entertainment Inc agreed to refrain from retaliating against venues that do not use its Ticketmaster service for every event in a settlement with the U.S. Justice Department, the government said on Thursday.
column6: Live Nation shares jumped 9% on Thursday.
column7: A 2010 consent order allowing Ticketmaster to merge with Live Nation barred it from strong arming concert venues into using the dominant ticket service. Instead, it “repeatedly and over the course of several years” violated that agreement, the Justice Department said in a statement.
column8: Reuters and others reported the expected legal action last week.
column9: “To put a stop to this conduct and to remove any doubt about defendants’ obligations under the Final Judgment going forward, the Department and Live Nation have agreed to modify the Final Judgment to make clear that such conduct is prohibited,” the department said.
column10: Live Nation acknowledged the settlement in a brief statement. “We believe this is the best outcome for our business, clients and shareholders as we turn our focus to 2020 initiatives,” the company said.
column11: The 2010 agreement had been set to expire next year but will now be extended five and a half years, the Justice Department said.
column12: Actions explicitly banned under the agreement include threatening to withhold future concerts if a venue does not use Ticketmaster, with an automatic $1 million penalty for each violation, the Justice Department said.

column4: Live Nation agrees to settle with DOJ over ticketing practices
column5: Dec 19 (Reuters) - Live Nation Entertainment Inc said on Thursday it had agreed to settle with the Department of Justice over the concert promoter’s ticketing practices.
column6: Live Nation’s shares rose 9% in afternoon trade.
column7: The DoJ was preparing to take legal action against Live Nation on allegations it has sought to strong-arm concert venues into using its dominant Ticketmaster subsidiary, Reuters reported last week, citing a source familiar with the matter.
column8: The Justice Department had allowed Live Nation and Ticketmaster to merge in 2010 on condition they abide by a range of conditions to keep ticket prices in check, including agreeing to be barred from retaliating against venue owners who use a competing ticket service.
column9: "We have reached an agreement in principle with the Department of Justice to extend and clarify the consent decree," Live Nation said reut.rs/38Y2uaI, without revealing further details.
column10: CNBC earlier in the day reported cnb.cx/2MdW9ya that the terms of the merger settlement, which was meant to expire in July 2020, will be extended by an additional five and a half years through December 2025. (Reporting by Bharath Manjesh in Bengaluru; Editing by Maju Samuel)

column4: U.S. Justice Department preparing legal action against Live Nation: source
column5: (Reuters) - The U.S. Justice Department is preparing to take legal action against Live Nation Entertainment LYV.N on allegations the concert promoter has sought to strong-arm concert venues into using its dominant Ticketmaster subsidiary, a source familiar with the planned legal action said on Friday.
column6: The department believes the concert promoter’s conduct has violated the merger settlement Live Nation and Ticketmaster reached with the government in 2010 and plans to file a decree enforcement action, the source said.
column7: The Wall Street Journal was first to report the planned legal action on Friday.
column8: Live Nation did not respond to a request for comment.
column9: The Justice Department allowed the companies to merge on condition they abide by a range of conditions to keep ticket prices in check, including agreeing here to be barred from retaliating against venue owners who use a competing ticket service.
column10: As ticket prices rise and the settlement is set to expire next year, the government now plans to extend the restrictions by several years and prohibit coercive conduct by Live Nation.
column11: With the merger, the company became an entertainment giant that does everything from managing musicians, operating venues, promoting concerts and selling tickets.
column12: In a filing to the U.S. government, Live Nation said it had worked on 35,000 events with more than 4,500 artists in 2018. It also said that Live Nation owns, operates, has exclusive booking rights for or an equity interest in 237 venues, including the House of Blues.
column13: Its management business worked with more than 400 artists, the filing said.

column4: UK competition watchdog flags concerns on Live Nation-MCD merger
column5: July 11 (Reuters) - Britain’s competition watchdog said on Thursday the proposed takeover of Ireland-based MCD Productions by the joint venture owned by U.S.-based Live Nation raises competition concerns in the music promotion industry in Northern Ireland.
column6: “There are only a few rival music promoters in the region and they mainly rely on Ticketmaster to sell tickets to their events,” the Competition and Markets Authority said in a statement.
column7: Ticketmaster is owned by Live Nation and the competition watchdog is concerned that the U.S. company may be able to stop rival promoters from selling tickets through the platform if the merger goes ahead.
column8: The joint venture, London-based LN-Gaiety Holdings Limited, is between live events promoter Live Nation Entertainment and Gaiety Investments. (Reporting by Yadarisa Shabong; Editing by Arun Koyyur)
